excerpt: Ruins of a luxury Roman 2nd century dwelling with replica bronze faun statue & preserved mosaics.
detail_description: The House of the Faun is a remarkable 2nd-century Roman dwelling in Pompeii, Italy. It is the largest house in Pompeii and features a replica bronze statue of the Dancing Faun, as well as the famous mosaic of the Battle of Alexander. The ruins also hold preserved mosaics and offer a glimpse into ancient Roman life.
name: House of the Faun

excerpt: Pompei is a city in southern Italy’s Campania region overlooked by the active volcano at Vesuvius. It’s known for its ancient city, Pompeii, which was buried by the 79 A.D. eruption of Mount Vesuvius. Ruins here include the frescoed Villa of the Mysteries and the city's amphitheater. In town, the Catholic pilgrimage site of the Sanctuary of the Madonna of the Rosary has mosaics and a grand cupola .
detail_description: Pompei, located in southern Italy's Campania region and overlooked by the active Vesuvius volcano, is famous for its ancient city buried by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 A.D. The ruins include the well-preserved Villa of the Mysteries and an amphitheater. Additionally, it houses the Catholic pilgrimage site of Sanctuary of the Madonna of the Rosary with stunning mosaics and a grand cupola.
name: Pompei

excerpt: Roman villa from the 2nd century BCE, richly decorated with frescoes with unknown meanings.
detail_description: Villa dei Misteri, a Roman villa dating back to the 2nd century BCE, is located at the northwestern edge of Pompeii. The villa boasts well-preserved and richly decorated frescoes that depict the initiation of a young bride into the mysteries of the cult of Dionysus. These vibrant frescoes, painted in glowing Pompeiian red, are found throughout many rooms, with the finest ones adorning the triclinium.
name: Villa dei Misteri
address: Via Villa dei Misteri, 2, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

excerpt: Ruins of Roman brothel preserved by ash with frescoes on the ground floor of 2-floor building.
detail_description: Lupanare di Pompei, also known as the 'wolfs den,' is a significant site within the ruins of Pompeii. This Roman brothel, consisting of two levels with five small cells on each floor, offers a glimpse into the intimate side of Roman life. Each cell features a stone bed topped with a mat or cushion and an erotic fresco above the door, likely depicting the specialization of the prostitute working in that cell.
name: Lupanare di Pompei
address: Via Villa dei Misteri, 2, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

excerpt: Remains of a 1st-century Roman bath complex with ornately decorated ceilings & wall carvings.
detail_description: The Forum Baths are the remains of a 1st-century Roman bath complex featuring intricately decorated ceilings and wall carvings. Situated near the forum, these baths include hot, warm, and cold baths, dressing rooms, and a public latrine. The large marble basin in the caldarium is adorned with donor names, while bronze benches with cow feet add to the unique features.
name: Forum Baths
address: Via del Foro, 26, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

excerpt: Famous high-end residence with richly colored frescos that was preserved when Mt. Vesuvius erupted.
detail_description: The House of the Vettii is a well-known and luxurious residence in Pompeii, famous for its richly colored frescos and statues.
name: Casa dei Vettii
address: Vicolo dei Vetti, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

excerpt: Restored Pompeiian home featuring abundant ornamental detail, including a colorful animal mosaic.
detail_description: The House of the Tragic Poet, located in the western part of Pompeii, is a restored home known for its intricate decorations. The house boasts colorful frescoes and mosaics, with a particularly striking mosaic depicting actors backstage. This led experts to speculate that an esteemed poet or writer may have resided here. The name of the house comes from a mosaic portraying an actor preparing for a performance.
name: House of the Tragic Poet
address: Vicolo Della Fullonica, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

excerpt: Former vineyard where the bodies of 13 victims of Vesuvius' eruption were found & cast in plaster.
detail_description: The Garden of the Fugitives, also known as the Garden of the Skeletons, is a former vineyard in Pompeii where 13 victims of Mount Vesuvius' eruption were found and cast in plaster. The site is named after these plaster casts, which depict the haunting last moments of the victims' lives. Over time, layers of ash and pumice preserved their bodies before they rotted away, leaving voids that were later filled with plaster to create these poignant displays.
name: Garden of the Fugitives
address: Vicolo dei Fuggiaschi, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

excerpt: Excavated mansion of a wealthy family, with a colonnaded walkway around the garden & faded frescoes.
detail_description: The House of Menander, an impressive Roman mansion in Pompeii, provides a fascinating glimpse into the opulent lifestyle of its wealthy inhabitants. This beautifully excavated residence features a stunning colonnaded walkway that encircles a lush garden and showcases faded frescoes that tell stories from ancient times. Among its treasures are exquisite mosaics and remnants of a lavish bath complex, all reflecting the grandeur of elite Roman life.
name: House of Menander

excerpt: Ruins of a 20,000-capacity Roman amphitheater where gladiatorial combats were held.
detail_description: The Amphitheatre of Pompeii is a remarkable ancient Roman ruin that once held up to 20,000 spectators for gladiatorial combats and other performances. This historic site offers visitors a chance to step back in time and experience the reality of living in a Roman settlement. Built around 70 BC, it predates the Colosseum by over a century, making it the oldest known amphitheatre of its kind.
name: Amphitheatre of Pompeii

excerpt: Ruins of Pompeii's 2nd-century-BC administrative center with Corinthian colonnades & Ionic capitals.
detail_description: The Basilica in Pompeii is a remarkable 2nd-century-BC administrative center with stunning Corinthian colonnades and Ionic capitals. The area underwent extensive excavations between 1907 and the 1950s, leading to the discovery of significant structures like the Temple of Peace, comitium, Porta Marina street, amphitheater, Temple of Ceres, and more. This ancient town offers a unique opportunity to step back in time and experience Roman life firsthand.
name: Basilica
address: Vicolo delle Terme, 2, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

excerpt: Ruins of temples, municipal buildings & the basilica in the social & civic center of the Roman town.
detail_description: Foro di Pompei, located in the ancient city of Pompeii, offers a captivating glimpse into Roman life. The well-preserved ruins include temples, municipal buildings, and the basilica at the social and civic center of the town. Buried under volcanic ash from Vesuvius' eruption in AD 79, visitors can wander through Roman streets and explore houses, shops, cafes, amphitheaters, and even a brothel.
name: Foro di Pompei
address: Via Villa dei Misteri, 2, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

detail_description: The Granaries of the Forum in Pompeii is a significant area within the ancient city, featuring a large square with triumphal arches, public buildings, temples dedicated to various deities, and spaces for civic, religious, and commercial activities. This pedestrian-only space was central to daily life in Pompeii. Visitors can explore well-preserved houses, baths, shops, and temples while learning about the city's social organization and cultural significance from knowledgeable guides.
name: Granaries of the Forum
address: Via degli Augustali, 12, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

detail_description: As you embark on your journey to the ancient city of Pompeii, make sure to start at Porta Marina Superiore, the main entrance that welcomes visitors with its impressive structure. This gateway leads you into a world where history comes alive through remarkable Roman architecture. Once inside, you'll find yourself in the bustling Forum, surrounded by significant landmarks like the Basilica and temples dedicated to Zeus and Apollo.
name: Porta Marina

excerpt: This horseshoe-shaped Roman theater was preserved by the volcanic eruption of Mount Vesuvius.
detail_description: The Teatro Grande, also known as the Large Theatre, is a horseshoe-shaped Roman theater in Pompeii that was remarkably preserved by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius. With seating for 5,000 spectators and stunning views over Pompeii and Mount Vesuvius, it offered fantastic acoustics for musical performances and plays. Dating back to the Samnite era, this grand structure features a cavea divided into three levels and a velarium to protect spectators from the elements.
name: Teatro Grande

detail_description: The Antiquarium di Pompei, constructed by Giuseppe Fiorelli in the 19th century, is located below the terrace of the Temple of Venus. It used to exhibit artifacts representing daily life in ancient Pompeii and casts of victims from the eruption. The museum now houses paintings found in Roman villas destroyed by Vesuvius in A.D.79.
name: Antiquarium di Pompei

detail_description: Don't miss out on visiting the Palestra Grande, also known as the great gymnasium of Pompeii. This expansive sports complex has been transformed into an archaeological museum where visitors can explore excavated artifacts from Pompeii. It is one of the best-preserved examples of Roman sports facilities, used for training, physical education, and hosting athletic competitions. Covering an area of approximately 6,500 square meters, it features a central courtyard surrounded by various rooms that served different sporting purposes.
name: Palestra Grande

detail_description: Terme Stabiane in Pompeii offers a fascinating glimpse into Roman bathing rituals and engineering sophistication. These well-preserved public baths, dating back to 125 BC, feature changing rooms, saunas, and a central swimming pool. Originally built in the 19th century at the request of King Francis of Bourbon, the complex was later expanded and modified by various architects.
name: Terme Stabiane

excerpt: Archaeological site of the remains of the iconic Roman city  preserved by Vesuvius' ash.
detail_description: The Archaeological Park of Pompeii is a remarkable site that preserves the remains of the ancient Roman city, which was buried under ash and lava during the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD. The vastness of the excavated ruins showcases the impressive extent of Roman civilization frozen in time. Rediscovered in 1599, detailed archaeological investigations began two centuries later, revealing a wealth of historical treasures.
name: Archaeological Park of Pompeii

excerpt: This small Roman temple honoring the Egyptian goddess Isis was an early excavation in Pompeii.
detail_description: The Temple of Isis is a small Roman temple located in Pompeii, dedicated to the Egyptian goddess Isis. It was one of the early excavations in Pompeii and has historical significance due to its preservation and plundering. The temple was built around 690 BC and continued to be a place of worship for the cult of Isis until at least AD 550.
name: Temple of Isis
address: Via del Tempio d’Iside, 30, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

detail_description: The House of Sallust is a 4th century BC monument which was excavated with the house. The election notice recommended a gentleman called Gaius Sallustius for office. The last owner was Cosso Libanio.
name: House of Sallust

detail_description: Pompei Scavi Villa Dei Misteri is easily accessible by Circumvesuviana trains from Napoli Porta Nolana Station and Napoli Piazza Garibaldi Station, with frequent departures throughout the day. The station itself has a charming, albeit worn-down, atmosphere that adds to its appeal. Visitors should plan for a full-day exploration of this ancient city, as it spans over six miles and offers an immersive journey through history.
name: Pompei Scavi Villa Dei Misteri

detail_description: Pompeii is a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts and those seeking a glimpse into ancient Roman life. A guided tour of Pompeii by an archaeologist offers insight into the city's fascinating past, followed by free time in the charming coastal town of Sorrento. The journey to Pompeii from Rome is made convenient with comfortable mini-coach transportation. Additionally, visitors can take advantage of luggage storage facilities at the nearby train station for added convenience.
name: Pompei

excerpt: Iconic remaining columns of a Roman temple dating back to 6th century BC framing Mount Vesuvius.
detail_description: Santuario di Apollo, located in Pompeii, is a significant religious site dating back to the 6th century BC. It features iconic columns framing Mount Vesuvius and is strategically positioned along the city's main gate. The sanctuary houses various statues of Ancient Roman gods, including Apollo and Diana. Additionally, it was dedicated to Apollo and hosted gladiatorial games and theatrical performances.
name: Santuario di Apollo
address: Via Villa dei Misteri, 4, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

detail_description: Ristorante Anfiteatro is a charming dining spot located just outside the amphitheater, offering a variety of seafood dishes including the rare salt cod. It's an ideal place to unwind after exploring the ruins of Pompeii, conveniently situated near one of the entrances. Guests can enjoy dining under the shade of a beautiful wisteria tree while receiving attentive service. The menu mainly features gamberi and other fish options, with commendations for their Caesar salad and pizza.
name: Ristorante Anfiteatro

detail_description: B&B Pompei Scavo Pompei Cave Canem is a charming and well-maintained accommodation located near the House of the Tragic Poet in Pompeii. The owner, Peppe, warmly welcomes guests and provides helpful advice on exploring the area. The rooms are clean and comfortable, with thoughtful details such as a small kitchenette. Guests can enjoy a delicious breakfast served in-room with attention to detail.
name: B&B Pompei scavo Pompei cave canem
address: Via Vittorio Emanuele, 8, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

detail_description: Diomede's Villa, also known as Villa di Diomede, is a prominent site in Pompeii. It is named after the tomb of Marcus Arrius Diomedes found inside. The villa features a triclinium with a stunning sea view and covers an extensive area of 3500 m2. Visitors can explore the well-reconstructed site with an enchanting garden and remnants of private thermae.
name: Diomede's Villa

detail_description: When visiting Scavi di Pompei, it's important to be mindful of the train stations, as some maps may only list them as 'Pompei.' Booking a guide is recommended for a more comprehensive experience, especially considering the vastness of the site. The upper entrance near the train station is convenient for access. The ruins are expansive and not very accessible for those with mobility issues.
name: Scavi di Pompei
address: Viale delle Ginestre, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

excerpt: Ancient stone temple ruins with columns & part of a Jupiter statue dating from the 2nd century BCE.
detail_description: Nestled within the ancient city of Pompeii, the Temple of Jupiter stands as a remarkable testament to Roman architecture and devotion. Dating back to the 2nd century BCE, this impressive structure features remnants of grand columns and fragments of a once-magnificent statue of Jupiter. The temple is strategically located near other significant sites like the Temple of Venus and the oldest Temple of Apollo, creating a rich tapestry of history in this archaeological wonderland.
name: Temple of Jupiter
address: Via degli Augustali, 12, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

excerpt: Historic archeological site featuring ruins of a Roman temple complex & views of the Gulf of Naples.
detail_description: The Temple of Venus is a historic archaeological site in Pompeii, dating back to the second century BC. Dedicated to Venus, the protectress of the city and navigation, it once featured expansive marble decorations and housed a large gold lamp donated by Nero and Poppea. The temple's third style includes miniature paintings depicting landscapes, birds, and sea creatures. Although now largely fallen down, it still offers colorful frescoes dedicated to Venus and a detailed statue of Mars.
name: Temple of Venus in Pompeii

excerpt: Remains of a centuries-old food market, with a central structure defined by 12 column bases.
detail_description: Macellum is the remains of an ancient food market in Pompeii, dating back to the 2nd century BC. It was the city's main produce market and featured a central structure defined by 12 column bases. The site also includes a small sanctuary, the Temple of Vespasian, and the headquarters of the woolen industry. The large basilica within Macellum is architecturally significant and provides insight into the origin and development of Christian basilicas.
name: Macellum
address: Via degli Augustali, 12, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

detail_description: Triangular Forum, located in a city center, served as the hub for religious, economic, and municipal activities. The large rectangular area was enclosed by a two-story colonnaded portico. At its northern end stood the temple dedicated to the Capitoline triad of deities: Jupiter, Juno, and Minerva. To the east lay the Macellum, a significant provision market. This archaeological wonder is impossible to fully appreciate in just one day due to its vastness.
name: Triangular Forum
address: Via Masseria Curato, 2, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

detail_description: Il Tempio Di Giove, built in the 2nd-century BC to honor Jupiter, Juno, and Minerva, was a center of religious activity. Visitors staying at the B&B nearby praised the owner for his hospitality and delicious breakfasts served on a terrace with a view of Vesuvius. The rooms were described as clean and comfortable. Although slightly off the beaten path, guests enjoyed their stay due to the kind and helpful owner and reasonable prices.
name: Il Tempio Di Giove

detail_description: Teatro Piccolo, also known as the Odeon or small theater, is a well-preserved ancient structure in Pompeii. Built around 79 BC, it could accommodate around thirteen hundred people and was ideal for poetry, music concerts, singing, and miming performances. Adjacent to the larger Teatro Grande (Large Theatre), this intimate venue offers a glimpse into the leisure activities enjoyed by ancient Pompeiians.
name: Teatro Piccolo

excerpt: Part of the larger Pompeii necropolis, this area contains tombs of prominent Roman-era citizens.
detail_description: Necropoli di Porta Ercolano is a part of the larger Pompeii necropolis and houses tombs of prominent Roman-era citizens. It is located along the road leading to Naples and dates back to the first centuries of Pompeii's existence. The funerary buildings visible today date back to the 1st century BC, illustrating prevalent funerary typologies of that time. The site features various tombs surrounded by nature, creating a calm and relaxing atmosphere.
name: Necropolis of the Herculaneum Gate
address: Villa delle Tombe, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

excerpt: Boscoreale is an Italian comune and town in the Metropolitan City of Naples, Campania, with a population of 25,939 in 2022. Located in the Vesuvius National Park, under the slopes of Mount Vesuvius, it is known for the fruit and vineyards of Lacryma Christi del Vesuvio. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Boscoreale is a charming town in the Metropolitan City of Naples, Campania, Italy. Nestled in the Vesuvius National Park at the foot of Mount Vesuvius, it boasts a population of around 27,457 people. The area is renowned for its abundant fruit and vineyards producing the famous Lacryma Christi del Vesuvio wine. Additionally, Boscoreale is home to several ancient villas such as the well-known Villa of the Mysteries.
name: Boscoreale

detail_description: Praedia di Giulia Felice is a sprawling ancient complex dating back to the 1st century BC, making it one of the earliest residences discovered during excavations. This patrician villa boasts expansive gardens surrounding several residential buildings and thermal baths. Named after an inscription found on its facade, this site offers well-preserved villas such as the House of the Faun, Villa of Julia Felix, House of Menander, and Villa of the Mysteries.
name: Praedia di Giulia Felice
address: Piazza Bartolo Longo, 37, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

detail_description: When visiting Pompeii, one of the fascinating spots to explore is the Thermopolium. These ancient fast food stores, dating back to before 79 AD, were a common feature in the city. They served as small cook shops where lower-class citizens who didn't have their own kitchens could purchase hot meals. The remains of these establishments can still be seen at the archaeological site today, offering a glimpse into the dining habits of ancient Pompeiians.
name: Thermopolium VI
address: Via delle Terme, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

detail_description: Reawakened Ancient City: Archaeological Areas of Pompeii is a mesmerizing historical site that offers a glimpse into the ancient Roman civilization. Visitors can wander through the remarkably preserved streets, homes, and public buildings of this once-thriving city. The site provides an immersive experience, allowing guests to envision daily life in Pompeii before it was tragically buried by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius. Exploring the archaeological areas reveals insights into ancient urban planning, architecture, and cultural practices.
name: Reawakened Ancient City: Archaeological Areas of Pompeii
address: Piazza Bartolo Longo, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

detail_description: Azienda Agricola Bosco de 'Medici is a family-owned estate with a rich heritage dating back to the early 1900s. The passion of grandfather Raffaele has been passed down through generations, and today, his nephews Emiddia, Sonia, Lella, and Giuseppe continue the legacy. The estate encompasses an eighteenth-century farmhouse wine cellar, Hotel Diana in Pompeii's center, and a Horse School.
name: Azienda Agricola Bosco de 'Medici
address: Via Antonio Segni, 43, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

excerpt: Iconic remaining columns of a Roman temple dating back to 6th century BC framing Mount Vesuvius.
detail_description: Santuario di Apollo is one of the oldest testimonies of the city, with origins dating back to the 6th century BC and having Hellenistic roots. The site features iconic remaining columns of a Roman temple that once framed Mount Vesuvius. Originally, a stunning mosaic adorned the floor, but only fragments remain visible today.
name: Santuario di Apollo
address: Via Villa dei Misteri, 4, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

detail_description: The Fullery of Stephanus was a laundry facility where clothes were washed and fabrics were degreased. It is believed that Stephanus, the owner, tried to escape as evidenced by a skeleton found at the entrance with a hoard of coins. The structure underwent excellent restoration work and originally started as a house before being transformed into a laundry. The atrium's impluvium was modified to create a basin for washing, while the compluvium was turned into a terrace for drying clothes.
name: Fullery of Stephanus

detail_description: The House of Venus in the Shell is a renowned Roman house located in Pompeii, featuring a remarkable fresco of Venus, the goddess of love, emerging from a shell. This first-century BC house boasts well-preserved and captivating frescoes depicting daily life scenes, mythological figures, and landscapes. The property has undergone several redecorations over time and is named after the striking monumental fresco adorning one of its walls.
name: House of Venus in the Shell

excerpt: Remains of an ancient Roman bathing house known for its well-preserved erotic wall paintings.
detail_description: The Suburban Baths, also known as Terme Suburbane, are an ancient Roman bathing house discovered by archaeologists in 1958. The site is famous for its well-preserved erotic wall paintings that caused a scandal when unearthed in 2001. Visitors can explore the remains of the heated outdoor swimming pool and view beautiful murals and mosaics throughout the bathhouse. Additionally, there is an amphitheater where gladiators once fought and citizens socialized.
name: Suburban Baths

excerpt: Centuries-old church with a Romanesque facade & a grand nave featuring marble pillars & frescoes.
detail_description: Basilica Sant'Antonino is a centuries-old church located in Sorrento, Italy. Its Romanesque facade and grand nave with marble pillars and frescoes make it a sight to behold. The basilica's origins date back to the 11th century when it was built on the remains of a 9th-century oratory dedicated to Saint Antonino, the city's patron saint.
name: Basilica Sant'Antonino

detail_description: The Casa degli Amorini Dorati, also known as the House of the Gilded Cupids, is a remarkable site in Pompeii. The house features well-preserved paintings and a roofless garden with original marble decorations. Its walls display various subjects such as still life, classical stories, cupids engaging in different activities, and more. Additionally, the interior architecture and restored courtyard add to its allure.
name: Casa degli Amorini Dorati
address: Via Dei Vesuvio, 80045 Pompei NA, Italy

name: Casa di Casca Longus o dei Quadretti Teatrali

excerpt: Large, excavated residence featuring sizable gardens with fountains & well-preserved artwork.
detail_description: This grand house from Pompeii features a large garden with fountains and well-preserved artwork, making it a great place to visit for feeling of ancient luxury life.
name: House of Octavius Quartio

detail_description: The Thermopolium, a popular eatery in ancient Rome, offered a variety of dishes such as dried legumes, chicory, soup, and fruits. Some establishments even had seating arrangements where guests were attended to by enslaved individuals, particularly women from distant lands. Patrons enjoyed their meals with wine while engaging in activities like gambling and sharing humorous anecdotes. However, Casa e Thermopolium di Vetutius Placidus, a remarkable historical site today, presents certain challenges.
name: Casa e Thermopolium di Vetutius Placidus
